description:
Project Goal:
To reduce post-harvest losses for smallholder farmers in Rwanda by introducing a cost-effective, solar-powered cold storage unit (2°C–8°C, 7-ton capacity). This will extend shelf life of perishables, improve income, enhance food security, and promote renewable energy use.
Background:
Agriculture employs over 70% of Rwandans, yet post-harvest losses exceed 30% for fruits and vegetables due to lack of cold storage. Conventional systems are expensive and impractical for off-grid areas. Leveraging Rwanda’s solar potential, we propose an affordable, energy-efficient cold room tailored to smallholder needs.
Research Question:
How effective is solar-powered cold storage in reducing post-harvest loss, extending shelf life, and boosting farmer income?
Objectives:
1.	Deploy a 7-ton solar cold room in a rural cooperative.
2.	Assess impact on spoilage, shelf life, and revenue.
3.	Evaluate cost-benefit and ROI.
4.	Explore scalability in Rwanda and East Africa.
Methods:
•	Design and install modular cold storage powered by solar PV and battery.
•	Train 100 farmers in post-harvest handling and storage use.
•	Collect baseline and post-intervention data on losses, revenue, and crop quality.
•	Analyze quantitative and qualitative results.
Expected Outcomes:
•	≥50% reduction in spoilage
•	20–30% increase in income
•	Full solar operation with reduced carbon footprint
•	Strengthened farmer cooperatives
•	Toolkit for national replication
Timeline (12 months):
Site selection (1–2), installation (3–4), training (5), operation & monitoring (6–10), analysis (11), dissemination (12)
Budget:
$40,000: Cold room & solar ($25k), installation ($5k), training ($3k), monitoring ($4k), contingency ($3k)
Conclusion:
This project tackles a critical barrier in Rwanda’s agricultural value chain by offering a sustainable cold storage solution. We seek partners to help scale impact and improve rural livelihoods.
name: Precision Crop Preservation With Energy Efficiency and Affordable Solution
